title: After loss to Warren, Republican John Deaton announces another run for Senate
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Republican John Deaton announces Senate run against Ed Markey after losing to Elizabeth Warren last year.
Deaton, a 58-year-old Marine veteran, emphasizes his youth and critiques Markey as a career politician.
Markey faces a primary challenge from Rep. Seth Moulton, with Deaton criticizing rising costs and promising to address them.

title: What will the Red Sox target this offseason? Craig Breslow maps out Boston’s priorities.
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox chief baseball officer Craig Breslow prioritizes finding a top pitcher to complement ace Garrett Crochet.
Boston may trade or sign a free-agent pitcher, considering options like Joe Ryan, Freddy Peralta, or Dylan Cease.
Beyond pitching, Boston aims to add power to their lineup, with targets including Kyle Schwarber and Pete Alonso.

title: Zdeno Chara’s 10 most memorable moments with the Bruins
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Zdeno Chara was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame, celebrated as a dominant NHL blueliner.
Chara captained the Boston Bruins for 14 seasons and led them to a Stanley Cup victory in 2011.
His career highlights include setting the record for the NHL's hardest shot at 108.8 mph in 2012.

title: Bill Belichick reflects on ‘learning curve’ during first season coaching college football
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Bill Belichick discusses his first season coaching UNC, acknowledging challenges adapting to college football.
UNC, under Belichick, holds a 4-5 record, needing two more wins to match the previous season's total.
Belichick reflects on missed early-season opportunities but notes team improvements after adjusting strategies.

title: Patriots have 15 players land on injury report, but get some good news
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Fifteen New England Patriots players were listed on the injury report ahead of the Thursday game against the Jets.
Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson were limited in practice after missing the previous game due to injuries.
Tight end Austin Hooper missed practice with a concussion, while multiple others were limited due to various injuries.

title: Georgia man allegedly stole millions in unclaimed Mass. property
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Shaka Stayman, from Atlanta, faces 25 charges related to stealing millions from Massachusetts' unclaimed property funds.
Stayman allegedly submitted seven fraudulent claims totaling $3.3 million using fake documents and ghost phone numbers.
He is held on $2 million cash bail and has a co-defendant, Dwight Tucker, scheduled for court arraignment.

title: TreVeyon Henderson explained why he looked at the sideline during key TD run
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: TreVeyon Henderson scored a key touchdown for the New England Patriots despite uncertainty about game strategy.
Henderson looked to the sideline for guidance during a crucial play, unsure if he should score immediately.
The rookie running back surpassed 100 yards and scored multiple touchdowns for the first time in his career.

title: Mason Lohrei is latest Bruins player to respond from a Marco Sturm benching
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mason Lohrei returned to the Boston Bruins lineup against Toronto after a five-game benching by coach Marco Sturm.
Lohrei made significant contributions in his return, recording two assists in Boston's 5-3 victory over the Maple Leafs.
Lohrei's defensive struggles led to his benching, but he responded with improved performance in the defensive zone.

title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: The Coalition for a Healthy Massachusetts is gathering signatures to repeal recreational marijuana, facing accusations of misleading tactics.
Voters report signing petitions under false pretenses, alleging misrepresentation on issues like affordable housing and marijuana legality.
State officials received complaints, but the Attorney General's Office has not confirmed any investigations into the matter.

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 — UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll totaled $9.19 billion in 2025, a decrease from $10.26 billion in the previous year.
UMass leaders dominated the payroll with all 15 top-paid positions; Frank Martin is the highest-paid earning $1.96 million.
UMass accounted for $1.55 billion in payroll expenditures; MBTA and Trial Court followed with $799.68 million and $574.67 million.
